snp3.12:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
snp3.12:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

snp3.12:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe pannarase puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
snp3.12:1.3.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.

snp3.12:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
snp3.12:1.4.eng: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent. He addressed them:

snp3.12:2.1.pli: “‘Ye te, bhikkhave, kusalā dhammā ariyā niyyānikā sambodhagāmino, tesaṃ vo, bhikkhave, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ariyānaṃ niyyānikānaṃ sambodhagāmīnaṃ kā upanisā savanāyā’ti, iti ce, bhikkhave, pucchitāro assu, te evamassu vacanīyā:
snp3.12:2.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘There are skillful teachings that are noble, emancipating, and lead to awakening. What is the real reason for listening to such teachings?’ You should answer:

snp3.12:2.2.eng: ‘Only so as to truly know the pairs of teachings.’

snp3.12:2.3.eng: And what pairs do they speak of?

snp3.12:3.1.eng: ‘This is suffering; this is the origin of suffering’: this is the first contemplation.

snp3.12:3.2.pli: Ayaṃ dukkhanirodho, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:3.2.eng: ‘This is the cessation of suffering; this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:3.3.pli: Evaṃ sammā dvayatānupassino kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
snp3.12:3.3.eng: When a mendicant meditates rightly contemplating a pair of teachings in this way—diligent, keen, and resolute—they can expect one of two results:

snp3.12:3.4.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
snp3.12:3.4.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

snp3.12:4.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

snp3.12:4.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
snp3.12:4.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

snp3.12:5.1.eng: “There are those who don’t understand suffering

snp3.12:5.5.eng: And they do not know the path

snp3.12:5.6.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

snp3.12:6.2.eng: as well as the release by wisdom.

snp3.12:6.4.eng: they continue to be reborn and grow old.

snp3.12:7.1.eng: But there are those who understand suffering

snp3.12:7.6.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

snp3.12:8.1.eng: They’re endowed with the heart’s release,

snp3.12:8.2.eng: as well as the release by wisdom.

snp3.12:8.4.eng: they don’t continue to be reborn and grow old.”

snp3.12:9.1.pli: ‘Siyā aññenapi pariyāyena sammā dvayatānupassanā’ti, iti ce, bhikkhave, pucchitāro assu;
snp3.12:9.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’

snp3.12:9.4.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ upadhipaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:9.4.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by attachment’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:9.5.pli: Upadhīnaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:9.5.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of attachment there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:9.6.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:9.7.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:10.2.eng: in all its countless forms in the world.

snp3.12:10.3.eng: When an ignorant person builds up attachments,

snp3.12:10.4.eng: that dullard returns to suffering again and again.

snp3.12:10.5.eng: So let one who understands <j>not build up attachments,

snp3.12:10.6.eng: contemplating the inception of suffering and rebirth.”

snp3.12:11.1.pli: ‘Siyā aññenapi pariyāyena sammā dvayatānupassanā’ti, iti ce, bhikkhave, pucchitāro assu;
snp3.12:11.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’

snp3.12:11.4.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ avijjāpaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:11.4.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by ignorance’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:11.5.pli: Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:11.5.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of ignorance there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:11.6.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:11.7.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:12.3.eng: they go from this state to another,

snp3.12:12.4.eng: that destination due only to ignorance.

snp3.12:13.1.eng: For ignorance is the great delusion

snp3.12:13.2.eng: because of which we have long transmigrated.

snp3.12:13.3.eng: Those beings who have arrived at knowledge

snp3.12:13.4.eng: do not proceed to a future life.”

snp3.12:14.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ saṅkhārapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:14.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by choices’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:14.4.pli: Saṅkhārānaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:14.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of choices there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:14.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:14.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:15.4.eng: there is no origination of suffering.

snp3.12:16.2.eng: that suffering is caused by choices;

snp3.12:16.3.eng: through the stilling of all choices,

snp3.12:16.5.eng: this is the way suffering ends.

snp3.12:16.6.eng: For those who truly know this,

snp3.12:17.4.eng: do not proceed to a future life.”

snp3.12:18.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ viññāṇapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:18.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by consciousness’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:18.4.pli: Viññāṇassa tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:18.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of consciousness there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:18.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:18.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:19.4.eng: there is no origination of suffering.

snp3.12:20.2.eng: that suffering is caused by consciousness,

snp3.12:20.3.eng: with the stilling of consciousness a mendicant

snp3.12:21.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ phassapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:21.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by contact’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:21.4.pli: Phassassa tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:21.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of contact there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:21.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:21.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:22.2.eng: swept down the stream of lives,

snp3.12:22.4.eng: are far from the ending of fetters.

snp3.12:23.1.eng: But those who completely understand contact,

snp3.12:24.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ vedanāpaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:24.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by feeling’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:24.4.pli: Vedanānaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:24.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of feeling there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:24.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:24.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:26.3.eng: they see it vanish with every touch:

snp3.12:26.4.comm: SN 36.2:3.4 has virajjati. See Bodhi’s note 1735 for the readings and commentary in both contexts.

snp3.12:26.5.eng: With the ending of feelings, a mendicant

snp3.12:27.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ taṇhāpaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:27.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by craving’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:27.4.pli: Taṇhāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:27.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of craving there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:27.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:27.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:28.2.eng: as they transmigrate on this long journey.

snp3.12:28.3.eng: They go from this state to another,

snp3.12:29.2.eng: that craving is the cause of suffering—

snp3.12:29.3.eng: rid of craving, free of grasping,

snp3.12:30.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ upādānapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:30.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by grasping’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:30.4.pli: Upādānānaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:30.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of grasping there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:30.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:30.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:31.1.eng: “Grasping is the cause of continued existence;

snp3.12:31.2.eng: one who exists falls into suffering.

snp3.12:31.3.eng: Death comes to those who are born—

snp3.12:31.4.eng: this is the origination of suffering.

snp3.12:32.1.eng: That’s why with the end of grasping,

snp3.12:32.3.eng: having directly known the end of rebirth,

snp3.12:32.4.eng: do not proceed to a future life.”

snp3.12:33.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ ārambhapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:33.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by instigating activity’: this is one contemplation.
snp3.12:33.3.comm: I take ārambha here as having the same sense as samārambha at AN 4.195:6.2. But see too the sense of “transgression” at AN 5.142:6.4.

snp3.12:33.4.pli: Ārambhānaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:33.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of instigation there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:33.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:33.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:34.4.eng: there is no origination of suffering.

snp3.12:35.2.eng: that suffering is caused by instigating activity,

snp3.12:35.4.eng: one is freed with respects to instigation.

snp3.12:36.1.eng: For the mendicant with peaceful mind,

snp3.12:36.2.eng: who has cut off craving for continued existence,

snp3.12:36.4.eng: there’ll be no more future lives for them.”

snp3.12:37.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ āhārapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:37.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by sustenance’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:37.4.pli: Āhārānaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:37.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of sustenance there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:37.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:37.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:38.4.eng: there is no origination of suffering.

snp3.12:39.2.eng: that suffering is caused by sustenance,

snp3.12:39.4.eng: one is independent of all sustenance.

snp3.12:40.1.eng: Having rightly understood the state of health,

snp3.12:40.3.eng: using after reflection, firm in principle,
snp3.12:40.3.comm: Saṅkhāya sevī refers to the monastic practice of making use of requisites, including food, only after reflection on them.

snp3.12:40.4.eng: a knowledge master cannot be reckoned.”

snp3.12:41.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti sabbaṃ iñjitapaccayāti, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:41.3.eng: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by perturbation’: this is one contemplation.

snp3.12:41.4.pli: Iñjitānaṃ tveva asesavirāganirodhā natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:41.4.eng: ‘With the utter cessation of perturbation there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:41.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:41.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:42.4.eng: there is no origination of suffering.

snp3.12:43.2.eng: that suffering is caused by perturbation,

snp3.12:43.3.comm: Text treats iñjita as eja and the translation should reflect this.

snp3.12:44.3.eng: ‘For the dependent there is agitation’: this is the first contemplation.

snp3.12:44.4.eng: ‘For the independent there’s no agitation’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:44.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:44.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:45.3.eng: goes from this state to another,

snp3.12:47.3.eng: ‘Formless states are more peaceful than states of form’: this is the first contemplation.

snp3.12:47.4.eng: ‘Cessation is more peaceful than formless states’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:47.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:47.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:48.1.eng: “There are beings in the realm of luminous form,

snp3.12:48.2.eng: and others stuck in the formless.

snp3.12:49.1.eng: But the people who completely understand form,

snp3.12:50.3.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya idaṃ saccanti upanijjhāyitaṃ tadamariyānaṃ etaṃ musāti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:50.3.eng: ‘What this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—focuses on as true, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually false’: this is the first contemplation.
snp3.12:50.3.comm: In this unique formulation, upanijjhāyati should be understood in terms of its consistent usage in the suttas: the excessive and obsessive focusing or gazing on something. It’s not just that people miss what is true, it is that they are looking intently in the wrong direction.

snp3.12:50.4.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa …pe… sadevamanussāya idaṃ musāti upanijjhāyitaṃ, tadamariyānaṃ etaṃ saccanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:50.4.eng: ‘What this world focuses on as false, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually true’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:50.5.eng: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”

snp3.12:50.6.eng: Then the Teacher went on to say:

snp3.12:51.1.eng: “See how the world with its gods

snp3.12:52.1.eng: For whatever you imagine it is,

snp3.12:52.2.eng: it turns out to be something else.

snp3.12:52.3.eng: And that is what is false in it,

snp3.12:52.4.eng: for the ephemeral is deceptive by nature.

snp3.12:53.2.eng: the noble ones know it as truth.

snp3.12:54.1.pli: ‘Siyā aññenapi pariyāyena sammā dvayatānupassanā’ti, iti ce, bhikkhave, pucchitāro assu;
snp3.12:54.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’

snp3.12:54.4.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya idaṃ sukhanti upanijjhāyitaṃ, tadamariyānaṃ etaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ, ayamekānupassanā.
snp3.12:54.4.eng: ‘What this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—focuses on as happiness, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually suffering’: this is the first contemplation.

snp3.12:54.5.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa …pe… sadevamanussāya idaṃ dukkhanti upanijjhāyitaṃ tadamariyānaṃ etaṃ sukhanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ, ayaṃ dutiyānupassanā.
snp3.12:54.5.eng: ‘What this world focuses on as suffering, the noble ones have clearly seen with right wisdom to be actually happiness’: this is the second contemplation.

snp3.12:54.6.pli: Evaṃ sammā dvayatānupassino kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
snp3.12:54.6.eng: When a mendicant meditates rightly contemplating a pair of teachings in this way—diligent, keen, and resolute—they can expect one of two results:

snp3.12:54.7.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitāti.
snp3.12:54.7.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

snp3.12:54.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

snp3.12:54.9.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
snp3.12:54.9.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

snp3.12:55.2.eng: touches, and ideas, the lot of them—

snp3.12:55.4.eng: as long as you can say that they exist.

snp3.12:56.1.eng: For all the world with its gods,

snp3.12:56.2.eng: this is what they deem happiness.

snp3.12:56.4.eng: is deemed as suffering for them.

snp3.12:57.1.eng: The noble ones have seen as happiness

snp3.12:57.3.eng: This insight by those who see

snp3.12:58.2.eng: the noble ones say is suffering.

snp3.12:58.4.eng: the noble ones know as happiness.

snp3.12:59.1.eng: See, this teaching is hard to understand,

snp3.12:59.3.eng: There is darkness for the shrouded;

snp3.12:59.4.eng: blackness for those who don’t see.

snp3.12:60.2.eng: like light for those who see.

snp3.12:60.3.eng: Though close, they do not understand,

snp3.12:60.4.eng: those fools inexpert in the teaching.

snp3.12:61.1.eng: They’re mired in desire for continued existence,

snp3.12:61.2.eng: flowing along the stream of lives,

snp3.12:61.4.eng: this teaching isn’t easy for them to understand.

snp3.12:62.1.eng: Who, apart from the noble ones,

snp3.12:62.2.eng: is qualified to understand this state?

snp3.12:63.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

snp3.12:63.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
snp3.12:63.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

snp3.12:63.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne saṭṭhimattānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
snp3.12:63.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.
